cinderclient/client.py.message: Maybe I have a bad sample, but in other openstack clients (e.g., change I19fb971de864), this is kept as 2 params, cert and key, and the tuple-ization is done in the code before handing off to requests.  The cinder-side change for mTLS in the connection to glance also has separate client cert and key parameters (change Ic9deaa001482).  I think we should be consistent with general openstack usage.

Regarding the format of cert option, I have followed the format supported and documented in keystoneauth code.
https://github.com/openstack/keystoneauth/blob/master/keystoneauth1/session.py#L288-L291

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
1. Please follow https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages
2. Technically it's a Change Request not a Patch Set
3. Example of good commit message:
  Update default CRI and cgroup driver

  Defautl CRI - contrinerd
  Default cgroup driver - systemd
4. Github issues must be linked via 'Closes:' or 'Relates-To:' keyword appended to the and of commit message for example 'Closes: #456' or 'Relates-To: #456'

Second line on commit message should be blank to separate subject and details sections of commit message

playbookconfig/src/playbooks/roles/boots.message: aligns with also metal kickstarts; and I suppose MINIMUM_TINY_DISK_SIZE=60 is accounted for in the virtual case
Yes. This was the existing comment. The variables needed to be moved for access.

Another option may be to wait until the size stops growing, as per:
https://github.com/LINBIT/drbd-utils/commit/b12e02eb8ac83aeb0a2165810d91dc3f5d20c83f ; it checks /sys/block/drbd%s/size   every 10secs.

As it looks like if resize2fs is done too soon, then recovery requires further increase to drbd size.

I think this is only an issue when there's a peer. In all my testing the resize was instantaneous. When testing I was able to rerun the resize2fs command as needed to update the filesystem size. So a replay of the playbook should address the issue. I would prefer to start with this and add the block size check if needed further down the line.
nit: character.  Assuming all sizes are in GB should be fine; etcd starts with 992MB and may lead to a false pass though the other fs would also fail and thus be detected as per observations so far.
Yeah I don't want the false positive if one fails because it starts at 1GB. I'll rework and include the above check for /sys/block/drbd%s/size

Does drbd always present 512 for device?

My concern would be if it's passed thru from the device, this value would work for 512n and 512e disks but for 4kn disks this might not be the correct value to use in the calculation below. 

You might want to consider using the following to get the presented value: blockdev --getss /dev/drbdX 

Similarly, block_size could be retrieved via: blockdev --getpbsz /dev/drbdX
Sounds like a good idea. For the block size is --getbsz safe?. In vbox getpbsz returns 512. Or I can just specify it in dumpe2fs, since I'm looking for the filesystem block size.
interesting - did we need to bump this up from 10 seconds (per iteration)?

This will end up waiting for 1 minute total. In my testing it never needed to wait, but I'd rather not have to revisit this if we find it takes slightly longer. The 15s is only if it fails the first time so this won't add time to the playbook unless it needs to.

well, you can even with condition.

    - name: Copy encypted keyfile to servers
      copy:
        src: "{{ item.src }}"
        dest: "{{ item.dest }}"
        owner: mysql
        group: mysql
        mode: 0600
        force: false  # only copy the file if it does not exist
      notify: Restart all mysql
      when: item.condition | default(True)
      with_items:
        - src: /tmp/keyfile.enc
          dest: /etc/mysql/encryption/keyfile.enc
          condition: "{{ (not galera_deployed | bool) }}"
        - src: /tmp/.keyfile.key
          dest: /etc/mysql/encryption/.keyfile.key

novajoin_tempest_plugin/tests/scenario/m.message: So is it possible to still use this as is with tempest 27.0.0?

It won't if CONF.scenario.img_file contains a full path because the execution won't fall in the condition. This code should make the transition (of removing img_dir from tempest.conf and setting img_file as full path) easier.
If we use the plugin with:
* img_dir defined (so img_file is not full path), tempest < 27.0.0 the warning will warn us about the change
* img_dir defined (so img_file is not full path), tempest >= 27.0.0 will fail
* img_dir not defined (so img_file is full path), tempest < 27.0.0 no warning, everything is working
* img_dir not defined (so img_file is full path), tempest >= 27.0.0 no warning, everything is working

It sounds like line 217 is going to fail if it's run with tempest 27.0.0 because tempest.config doesn't actually register that option anymore. So, this if statement is only intended to be executed when running tempest<27.0.0,>=25.0.0?
Ok - thank you for walking me through it.

It is, but only if CONF.scenario.img_dir is not defined

In tempest 27.0.0 and higher scenario.img_dir option can't be defined in the tempest.conf file because the option is removed [1] from tempest - it will raise an error when parsing tempest.conf (therefore the warning)

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tempest/+/754927/2/tempest/config.py

2019-11-22 13:32:38.047818 | controller | {0} tempest.scenario.test_volume_boot_pattern.TestVolumeBootPattern.test_boot_server_from_encrypted_snapshot_luks [25.930995s] ... ok

Well, I'm not sure what the QA team considers "slow" but I would generally only start applying that tag for tests that take longer than 60 seconds.
is attach_encrypted_volume required for booting server from encrypted snapshot?

Yes, this test will exercise most of the same codepaths as a normal attachment of an encrypted volume to an already running instance. I don't think we need another compute_feature just for booting from an encrypted volume.

Please create encrypted volume from the image, otherwise, you create an empty volume and nova boot has no meaning. you will try to load an empty device. I think you should verify that nova boot has done successfully

It actually exercises a huge amount of code without creating the encrypted volume from an image. The fact that the instance has launched and is ACTIVE is more than enough for this test IMHO.

Given this is an API test and not a scenario test I wanted to keep this light and avoid any validation within the instance that's often the source of failures in the gate.
All looks good, but Isn't it good if we can create a bootable volume from image and then use that too boot an instance ??

The volume would still need to be marked as bootable and as we aren't ssh'ing into the eventual instance I didn't see the need to create the encrypted volume from the image here tbh.

This test is really just exercising the code path from bug #1853495, if others want to add additional validation that's fine but I'd rather it be done as a follow up to this.
Once you boot the instance from snapshot with data , please verify nova shows : ( i dont remember the flags )

I can assert that the instance is booting from a volume but that's about it here.
Once the instance is "up" and running, please send a ping to verify that the cirros image is up and running.
Again I think this is pointless and error prone in API tests.
does it make sense to add here a similar assertEqual as is on line 269 but for snapshot or any other check confirming that the server was booted from the snapshot?

deployment/glance/glance-api-container-p.message: -1: Please name this something like GlanceCinderVolumeType. THT parameters that begin with "Cinder" are presumed to be cinder settings, and this is a glance setting.
Sure, will modify this in next patch set.

"None" is misleading, as all cinder volumes have an associated type. Perhaps you want to allow cinder to choose the default volume type? If that's the case then I recommend a default THT value such as '' (empty string).

I will pass empty string here in next patch set.

For single cinder store, cinder_volume_type should be None, I will pass empty string here.

For multiple cinder store, I'm thinking to provide below parameters values,
parameter_defaults:
  GlanceBackendID: cinder1
  GlanceBackend: cinder
  CinderVolumeType: lvmdriver-1
  GlanceStoreDescription: 'Default Cinder store'
  GlanceMultistoreConfig:
    cinder2:
      GlanceBackend: cinder
      CinderVolumeType: nfsdriver-1,
      GlanceStoreDescription: 'Second cinder store'
    cinder3:
      GlanceBackend: cinder
      CinderVolumeType: cephdriver-1,
      GlanceStoreDescription: 'Third Cinder store'
Conceptually, yes, but I assume you mean to use 'GlanceCinderVolumeType' everywhere (including in the GlanceMultistoreConfig value.

I find the entire description to be confusing, but this particular portion is troubling. If you're saying any volume type must already exist, then how will this work with fresh deployments? TripleO only provides support for specifying cinder's default volume type, and currently there's no way to specify additional volume types, or to have them associated with specific cinder backends. So I'm not sure how this is supposed to work.

Yes, TripleO currently only supports specifying cinder's default volume type.

Seems we would need to provide this support in cinder tripleo because for multiple cinder store support in glance, the volume types needs to be set for each cinder backend,

Ex, suppose we've 3 backends in cinder, lvm, nfs and ceph and 3 volume types in cinder pointing to each backend, lvmdriver-1, nfsdriver-1, cephdriver-1, on glance side we will have to set cinder_volume_type=lvmdriver-1 for store 1, cinder_volume_type=nfsdriver-1 for store 2 and cinder_volume_type=cephdriver-1 for store 3.

To make this work, we will require the OOO support for cinder volume_type

Please suggest if something else is in your mind, if the solution I've proposed is not doable.

This is definitely the direction we need to go for this feature to work, but we'll want to carefully consider how to handle it in TripleO. The general trend is to limit the use of puppet to configuring conf files, and use ansible for other tasks. I think we need to do some design work, and I would like to participate.
please add release notes for CinderVolumeType
Recommend something like "volume-type-1" and "-2" at L265. Mentioning both LVM and "driver" are potentially misleading because neither terms are associated with volume types.

L278 needs full-stop '.' to terminate the sentence.

L279 can probably be deleted, or maybe get reworded. You correctly mention the volume type must be configured in cinder, so maybe the point to make here is the volume type must exist prior to any attempt to add an image in the associated cinder store.

I'm still not sure of L280. There are circumstances where an admin may wish to specify a volume type for glance images even when there's just one cinder store. I think what you may want to say is specifying a volume type is optional.

Overall this patch is looking very good, but I find several nits with this last sentence:
- The opening and closing parentheses () are distracting and should be removed.
- No need to capitalize Volume, so lead with "The volume type..."
- AFAIK the volume type doesn't "exist" in glance (it's just a cinder concept).

It also probably helps the user to know that if GlanceCinderVolumeType isn't specified then images will be stored using cinder's default volume type. How about replacing L279..280 with something like this?

"The volume type must exist in cinder prior to any attempt to add an image in the associated cinder store. If no volume type is specified then cinder's default volume type will be used."
nit: don't need the line break between the - and if

doc/source/review-the-openstack-way.rst.message: is this a misplaced comma? It doesn't appear to fit

"Occasionally it is convenient to rely on the core-reviewer-only availability. Persistence over future patches and merge-blocking behavior of a Code Review -2 to temporarily prevent any other core reviewers from successfully approving a change even if the change itself is a desirable one..." (and then it feels like there should be something here?
Still very hard to grok sentence.

I feel it's important to make clear that these requirements (always explain what's happening; always remove the vote once the temporary condition has passed) apply whatever the reason for the procedural -2. We might need to refactor the text a little to do that.
This is a great point, I'm open to further adjustment of the existing sections to reflect this.
This sounds like a special case of a feature freeze, so +1 to documenting it.

Cool, this makes a really good case for mentioning the Priority label some teams have started to use, since a Priority -1 vote can also be used as a persistent merge blocker instead of reusing Code-Review -2 for that purpose.

Endorsing this makes me nervous TBH. What's wrong with "-1, I have some concerns, let's discuss this on the mailing list here: ..."?

-2ing a patch is just about the most unfriendly thing you can do to a new, or any, contributor ("If I ever got a -2 on one of my patches... I would cry" --actual thing once said to me by a new contributor), so there had better be a good reason for it.

If core reviewers can't trust each other to read previous comments before reviewing a patch then maybe that's a problem that should be solved between them rather than by hitting contributors with ever-larger hammers?
This is a fair point. While it does happen from time to time, it's perhaps not a case we'd want to actively endorse.

I agree with Zane. I believe the initiator of this patch was a discussion on the starlingx mailing list which is this *exact* case, a new contributor was given a -2. I personally don't think that is appropriate and would heavily suggest not codifying that.

Agreed, there is a "never in a million years" subtone to -2 -- we should keep those for cases where merging would be damaging (or hard to rollback), with proper explanation. I prefer the occasional revert in case someone accidentally bypasses a -1, than the negative message a casual use of a -2 sends.

Maybe we need a workflow -2 (like workflow -1 but sticky)?

Even if it is in effect the same thing as Code Review -2. Any vote labelled "Code Review" is likely to be interpreted by contributors as a judgement of their code. The more I think about it, the more it seems wrong to use it for workflow management purposes at all.

(Another benefit is that a core reviewer would be able to code review a patch even if they were also e.g. the person in charge of holding features back during a freeze, without ambiguity.)

The challenge there is that if a project adds -2 to the Workflow range, Gerrit will no longer consider -1 to prevent merging. See https://review.openstack.org/Documentation/config-labels.html for the label configuration options we have at our disposal right now (at least if we don't resort to writing prolog rules). Otherwise I agree this would be a nifty solution. A similar alternative would be to add a separate "Procedural" label with a -1..0 range limited to core reviewers.

I am not sure Procedural even needs to stay only for cores.

There are patchsets you may want to prevent merging until some things happen, and which are neither Work in progress nor Depends-On another task.
So they deserve a Workflow +1 Code review+x and Procedural -1 that sticks through rebases.

I would be in favour of adding a "Procedural" -1 that the owner of the patch and cores could adapt.

doc/source/ideas/dew.rst.message:
Is that really realistic?
I am afraid to burn people in over-optimization.

I like the noble goal of a "Tinkerer" having a single machine it can use openstack with, in an "All in one" manner.

Many deployment projects already offer that "All in one mode". Sadly they need more than 4GB of RAM :)

Relative to what? It's notably less powerful than a $55 Raspberry Pi, and the multitenancy features of OpenStack (which are the main thing it brings to the table) are not useful to a developer working on their own.

What are the level of the failures you want to target?
Are you talking about a compute node that goes down? Yes, you can continue operation, and if necessary, you can reschedule your workloads to start on a new node. But if you are talking about memory corruption, I doubt OpenStack will help fix hardware solution. My point is that there is a level of fault tolerance that isn't really obvious in this sentence.
I think VRRP is a more likely candidate. This means that the Keystone catalog does not need to be modified when services move. Substantially all highly-available deployments are already using this.
We already have a service catalog through keystone. I guess the first step would be, for this case, to build mDNS software to broadcast the services.
I am afraid this idea will make the software more complex to review, not less complex. Can you elaborate on what project could deserve this treatment?

I think if we ensure that the usual openstack services are accomodated for this purpose, then there is nothing else to do.
OpenStack already has packaging projects, and those can build the necessary artifacts for consumption.

OpenStack is a community where we build software together. IMO, we don't really build _a product_. That's up to product companies.

I think the fast forward case is sufficiently likely to happen that a test case for it would be worthwhile.

zuul/executor/server.py.message:
This seems safe, but I'm unable to convince myself that the comment is strictly true:

In doMergeChanges we call merger.mergeChanges which calls merger._mergeItem for every item.

In merger._mergeItem, if it's the first time we've seen a project-branch in this merge sequence, we restore the repo state for that repo, and then we save it.  The act of saving the repo state should not actually change the repo state since it immedaitely follows restoring it.

In the initial merge requested by the scheduler as part of enqueing, that does alter the repo state because it's initially empty and it populates the repo state as it goes.  But in the executor, we begin with a fully populated repo state, and therefore, the save call should be a no-op.
The child change of this change cleans this line up.

neutron/db/l3_db.py.message: I don't understand this check. Query in L1557 will return an empty list with the same DB query. This will duplicate the number of queries.

Understood. So, I'll reformulate my comment: why don't we reduce the scope of the L1557 query?

You can implement, inside the FloatingIP OVO class, a method to retrieve only the FIP ID filtering by "floating_network_id, "router_id", "fixed_port_id". This is a direct query, without joined ones, that will return 

  query = context.session.query(l3.FloatingIP.id)
  query = query.filter(and_(
    l3.FloatingIP.floating_network_id == floating_network_id,
    l3.FloatingIP.router_id == router_id,
    l3.FloatingIP.fixed_port_id == fixed_port_id)
  return query.all()  <-- list of IDs only, this query is trivial.

That will speed up both cases, when we have associated FIPs and not.
